question: Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of:
exp: Renshaw cells are inhibitory cells that transmit inhibitory signals to the surrounding motor neurons. This anterior motor neuron gets excitatory impulses from multiple sources, if all these excitatory inputs were sent to the muscles, muscle will fatigue early, so, there is some inherent check to reduce the excitability of these motor neurons & that is in form of Renshaw cell inhibition. This is recurrent type of inhibition. The inhibitory neurotransmitters Glycine and GABA are involved in Renshaw cell inhibition.

question: The perivascular space (Virchow-Robin space) in the brain is formed between the wall of small penetrating vessels and which structure?
exp: The perivascular space (Virchow- Robin space) is formed between the outer wall of small vessels penetrating into the brain and the pia mater, which lines the outer surface of the brain and is only loosely attached to the brain. It is an extension of the subarachnoid space which separates penetrating vessels from brain tissue.

question: Which electrical event is characteristic of inhibitory synaptic interactions?
exp: IPSP: Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential The opening of ligand-gated chloride channels and movement of chloride ions into the cell leads to hyperpolarization of the membrane. Neither increasing the extracellular sodium concentration nor the movement of potassium into the cell leads to hyperpolarization of the membrane. IPSP results in hyperpolarization of membrane. Glycine, GABA are the neurotransmitters involved.
opa: A neurotransmitter agent that selectively opens ligand-gated chloride channels is the basis for an inhibitory postsynaptic potential
opb: Because the Nernst potential for chloride is about -70 mV, chloride ions tend to move out of the cell along its electrochemical gradient
opc: A neurotransmitter that selectively opens potassium channels will allow potassium to move into the cell
opd: An increase in the extracellular sodium concentration usually leads directly to an inhibitory postsynaptic potential

question: Among the areas mentioned, the highest number of noradrenergic neurons is present in:
exp: Locus coeruleus has max number of nor-adrenergic neurons Nucleus raphe magnus has max number of serotonergic neurons Periaqueductal grey has max number of enkephalinic neurons Medial longitudinal fasciculus has max number of Dopaminergic neurons It is implicated in reward & addictive behavior But now nucleus accumbens is said to be involved in reward & addictive behavior

question: Noradrenergic neurons are chiefly present in:
exp: Cells in the locus ceruleus have noradrenergic neurons that are projected to all pas of the cerebral coex and limbic system. It is involved in the regulation of attention, arousal, sleep-wake cycles, mood and affect. Raphe nucleicontain serotonergic neurons. These neurons fire most rapidly during wakefulness Nucleus accumbens and nigro-striatal pathway contain dopaminergic neurons.

question: In a demyelinating disease (e. g. multiple sclerosis), symptoms worsen with hot bath and improve with decreased temperature because:
exp: In demyelinating diseases after myelin is degraded, there is redistribution of Na+ channels along the nerve (normally present at nodes of Ranvier). Lower temperature alters the Na+ channel kinetics in a way to delay the closure, thus extra Na+ can come into the cell, which enable electronic conduction upto the point on the nerve where the next Na+ channel is. At higher temperature: there is increased leakage of charges from the cell membrane k/o increased capacitance of the nerve.
opa: Lower temperatures slow the gating kinetics of Na+ channels
opb: AP duration increases with increased temperature
opc: Activity of K+ channels is increased at lower temperatures
opd: Inadequate recharging of the denuded axon at higher temperatures

question: Which ion has the lowest electrochemical driving force in a typical neuron with a resting membrane potential of -65 millivolts?
exp: The equilibrium potential for chloride averages about -70 millivolts in a typical neuron, so with a resting membrane potential of 65 millivolts, the electrochemical driving force for chloride is 5 millivolts. In case of neuron, equilibrium potential for: Potassium: -90 mV Sodium: +60 mV Calcium: +129 mV

question: Commonest inhibitory transmitter in the spinal cord is:
exp: GABA and glycine are the most common inhibitory transmitters in the CNS.

question: Low molecular weight neurotransmitters are all except:
exp: Low molecular weight neurotransmitters: (Small molecule transmitter) Glutamate GABA Ach NA Dopamine High molecular weight neurotransmitters: (Large molecule transmitter) NP Y Orexins Opioid CA

question: D2 receptors are maximally seen in:-
exp: The impoant pathways in the brain that release dopamine as transmitter: Nigrostriatal pathway in basal ganglia - The fibers convey from substantia nigra of the midbrain to the corpus striatum in basal ganglia. It is an impoant pathway in the control of voluntary movements. Mesolimbic system - From the midbrain to the limbic system. The pathway is impoant in the control of emotions and emotion-related movements.

question: Oligodendrocytes form myelin sheath in CNS. The cell -to-cell ratio (oligodendrocyte: neuron) for this myelination is:-
exp: Oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells are involved in myelin formation around axons in the CNS and peripheral nervous system, respectively. Oligodendrocytes are small with relatively few processes. Those in the white matter provide myelin, and those in the gray matter suppo neurons. One Oligodendrocytes myelinates 20 axons in CNS. This is the reason why CNS neurons doesn't repair.

question: An example of "autoreceptors" in the CNS is:
exp: Autoreceptor is a presynaptic receptor; binding of the NT with autoreceptor inhibits fuher secretion of the transmitter. a2-receptor for NE is an example of autoreceptor. NMDA receptor for glutamate is a voltage + ligand gated channel. Nicotinic AChR is a non-specific cation channel. GABA-C receptors are found exclusively in the retina; they are ionotropic receptors.

question: Regarding Neuroligins, false statement is:
exp: "Neurexins" is a presynaptic cell adhesion molecule which binds with postsynaptic molecule "Neuroligins" Interaction between them holds the synapse together and also provide synaptic specificity. They are responsible for synaptic function but not for formation of synapse. These have no role in neurotransmitter release. Mutations in the genes encoding these causes autisim spectrum disorder (ASD), Tourette syndrome, mental retardation, and schizophrenia.
opa: Hold the presynaptic and postsynaptic membranes together
opd: Mutation of these genes causes autisim spectrum disorder

question: Myelin sheath is absent in:-
exp: Myelin sheath is absent at following sites:- 1) Nodes of Ranvier 2) Proximal pa of Axon (Pre axon) 3) Near the termination of Axon. 4) At the clefts of Schmidt- Lantermann.

question: Scavenger cell in the CNS is:
exp: Microglia is the only cell that is borne out of CNS and moves into the CNS. It is formed from monocyte lineage in the bone marrow. It is physiologically and embryologically unrelated to other neural cell types It has phagocytic function hence known as "scavenger cell" in the CNS.

question: A 15-year-old girl is taken to see a physician because of a sore throat. An antibiotic is prescribed that can enter most tissues of the body but cannot penetrate the blood-brain barrier. The blood-brain barrier can be attributed primarily to which cell type?
exp: The endothelial cells lining all blood vessels in the brain constitute the blood-brain barrier. Tight junctions between endothelial cells forms blood-brain barrier. The purpose of the blood-brain barrier is to protect the chemical environment of the brain from rapid changes in composition that occur normally in the rest of the body fluids.

question: Compared to plasma, the CSF has a higher concentration of:
exp: Substance CSF concentration CSF: plasma ratio Na+ K+ Ca++ Chloride Mg++ Bicarbonate Protein Glucose 147 meq/L 2. 9 meq/L 2. 3 meq/L 113 meq/L 2. 2 meq/L 25. 1 meq/L 20 mg% 64 mg% 0. 98 0. 62 0. 49 1. 14 1. 39 1. 01 0. 003 0. 64

question: In central nervous system, the cell that scavenges the debris created after breakdown of an axon and its myelin:
exp: Macrophages are responsible for the phagocytosis of various cell debris in the body. Macrophages in various organs are given special names. eg: Kupffer cells - liver Microglia - brain Osteoclasts - bone Dust cells - lungs.

question: Post-tetanic facilitation is thought to be the result of which of the following?
exp: Post-tetanic facilitation is the neuronal phenomenon in which a neuron is more easily excited after a brief period of activity. This phenomenon is thought to be due to the buildup of calcium in the presynaptic membrane caused by the prior neuronal activity. Subsequent neuronal impulses release neurotransmitter more readily as a result of this preplaced calcium from the prior stimulus.
opc: A buildup of calcium in the presynaptic terminal

question: Which one of the following is not an ADVANTAGE of an electrical synapse over a chemical synapse, in the CNS?
exp: The events at the electrical synapses occur in narrow time frame; there is no latency, no synaptic delay, and the conduction is faster, as compared to a chemical synapse. Bidirectionality is a feature of electrical synapse which is not shown by chemical synapse. Plasticity is more marked at the chemical synapses. Amplification of signal, by means such as presynaptic facilitation and divergent synaptic circuits, is a feature of the chemical synapses

question: True about end plate potential (EPP) is:-
exp: Non-specific cation channel (same channels allow Na+ to come in & same channel allows K+ to go out) are acetylcholine-gated channels which opens and causes the electrical potential inside the fiber at the local area of the end plate to increase in the positive direction as much as 50 to 75 millivolts, creating a local potential called the end plate potential. EPP is a graded response. It doesn't obey all or none propey. Its amplitude decreases over distance and it can be summated. EPP develops conves into one AP. This action potential then travels.
opa: It occurs as a result of altered permeability for Na+ and K+
opc: It results from release of a single transmitter vesicle

question: A pool of presynaptic neurons innervate the dendrites of a postsynaptic neuron. Electrical signals are transferred from the dendrites to the soma of the postsynaptic neuron by which process?
exp: Transmission of electrical signals in dendrites occurs by electrotonic conduction.

question: Slow conduction velocity is seen with which of the following nerve fibers?
exp: Slow conduction velocity is seen in 'C'- fibers because they are unmyelinated. These are post ganglionic sympathetic nerve fibers.

question: "Blood brain barrier" is present at all of the following sites except:
exp: Some areas of the brain lack blood-brain barrier. These are called the circumventricular organs because they surround the ventricular system in the brain. They are supplied by leaky capillaries. These areas are: Area postrema (CTZ is located in this area) Posterior pituitary Subfornical organ (SFO) (a specialized receptor area in diencephalon; angiotensin II acts on it to stimulate thirst) Median eminence (poion of the hypothalamus from which the poal vessels arise) Pineal gland Organum vasculosum laminae terminalis (OVLT) (function similar to SFO)

question: Which of the following foramina allows cerebrospinal fluid to pass directly from the ventricular system into the subarachnoid space?
exp: The foramen of Magendie and the two lateral foramina of Luschka form the communication channels between the ventricular system within the brain and the subarachnoid space that lies outside the brain and spinal cord.

question: The peak of fast EPSP or, fast IPSP is seen at what time after stimulus application:
exp: Fast EPSP and fast IPSP begins 0. 5 ms after the stimulus (known as latency). They peak 1-1. 5 ms after the stimulus then decreases exponentially. Fast EPSP is due to influx of Na+ and or Ca++ in post synaptic neuron. Fast IPSP is due to influx of Cl- in post synaptic neuron.
